item.title: Perfectly Inelastic Collision
item.description: Topic: Linear Momentum Perfectly Inelastic Collision A collision in which the objects stick together. There is only one final velocity. In order to solve these problems, you use the Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum.

item.title: Linear Momentum
item.description: Linear Momentum \vec{P} = m\vec{v} Note that momentum has a direction, unlike Kinetic Energy. The rate of change of momentum is equal to the net force: \sum\limits \vec{F} = \frac{d\vec{P}}{dt} This feels quite natural as if there is no net force there will be no change in momentum.

item.title: Inelastic Collisions
item.description: Topic: Linear Momentum Inelastic Collisions A collision in which the total Kinetic Energy does not remain constant. Note the special case of Perfectly Inelastic Collision, where the objects stick together.

item.title: Velocity
item.description: Velocity Velocity is a vector that denotes how fast and in what direction something is moving. Mathematically, it is written as \vec{v} = \vec{x}/t where \vec{x} represents the displacement.

item.title: Rolling Motion
item.description: Topic: Angular Motion Rolling Motion Rolling motion occurs when there is translational and angular motion. For it to occur without slipping, v_{cm} = R \omega Where v_{cm} is the velocity of the center of mass, R is the radius of the rolling object, and \omega is the Angular Velocity.

item.title: Mass
item.description: Topic: Mass Mass is a measure of the amount of matter in an object. It is distinct from Weight. The SI unit for mass is the kilogram. References.
